unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from grays anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource. click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

using the emodule previous next use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of each page, swipe right or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking menu at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe left or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 18 18a prelab 18b prelab 18.1 the brain

previous got it, lets move on conventions used in the emodule tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k with age, wear and tear, info an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus. information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related information. click the icon to close it. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts

unit 6 care of human brain tissue previous next the brains with which you are supplied were fixed with formaldehyde, but they have been thoroughly rinsed with water to clear the formaldehyde, and are kept in water. brain tissue dries out very rapidly. keep the parts you are not using in the bucket, covered completely with a cloth, and with the lid on the bucket. moisten the parts you are using from time to time with water (not embalming fluid). a brown colouration on the edges of the brain tissue is a cry for moisture. look around yourself in the lab. you will see buckets labelled human tissue only. all waste tissue must be placed in the "human tissue only" buckets that are present in every laboratory. do not put waste tissue in the trolleys under the tables; these are dedicated containers for the remains of the cadaver(s) on that table. used paper towels and gloves go in the garbage, never in the human tissue only receptacles. trays, instruments and table tops are to be cleaned with cleaning fluid and paper towels. remember: the teaching labs are used by other student groups, and so must be left as you found them: clean and ready for student use.

unit 6 overview previous next we have been challenged with teaching / learning neuroanatomy over a short period of time. its critical that you learn what i teach, as i teach it. with neuroanatomy, more so than any other topic in anatomy, each lesson builds on the last. you will only frustrate yourself if you do delay learning. in unit 6, there is a lot more content that ill assign in the form of self-learning modules. i do, however, walk you through a fair bit of it using slide talks. clinical neuroanatomy is ultimately about two questions: 1) where is the lesion? and 2) what is the lesion? you first must learn some neuroanatomy before you can localize a lesion, so youll start with that. labs are run differently in unit 6. groups will be smaller (4-5 people) because the specimens you will study, brains and brainstems, are smaller. at stg, each lab room is equipped with 8 stations, each of which includes a whole brain and a half brain. stg students will be divided into 8 groups as follows: pairs 1 (a1 & b1) on the left side of the room go to one table, forming group ab1 pairs 2 (a2 & b2) on the left side of the room go to the next table, forming group ab2 pairs 3 (a3 & b3) on the left side of the room go to the third table, forming group ab3 pairs 4 (a4 & b4) on the left side of the room go to the fourth table, forming group ab4 similarly, on the right side of the room, four groups are formed designated cd1, cd2, cd3 and cd4. some resources are limited; you will rotate through the practical exercises in these groups so as to equitably share the specimens. at mam, students are divided into six groups of 4-5 students each. your ta will fill you in on the details.

lab 18 instructions previous take me to exercise selection prior to lab 18, you will complete slm 18a, on the anatomy of the spinal cord and slm 18b, on the meninges and associated bleeds. the lab will begin with an app-based quiz on these slms. during lab you will complete three exercises: 18.1, in which you will study the brain and functional localization, 18.2, in which you will study the coverings of the brain, and 18.3, in which you will study the surface features of the brainstem and its associated cranial nerve roots. review these exercises before the lab so that your time in lab is used efficiently. in particular, review the brief videos in these exercises prior to lab. you mustnt look at them for the first time during the lab time! i warn you that this is a large amount of material that you must learn during this period using the specimens provided. lab 19, on monday, includes four prelab slms plus practical exercises each of which builds on the lab 18 exercises; if you think that you can learn it later, you will only frustrate yourself. 18.4 is a field trip to grants museum, where there are outstanding dissections of the brain and brainstem. lab start - 2:30 pm 2:30-3:45 pm 3:45-5:00 pm 18.1 the brain stg: ab1, ab2, ab3 mam: a12, a34 stg: cd2, cd3, cd4 mam: b12, b34 stg: ab4, cd1 mam: c12, c34 18.2 coverings stg: ab4, cd1 mam: c12, c34 stg: ab1, ab2, ab3 mam: a12, a34 stg: cd2, cd3, cd4 mam: b12, b34 18.3 the brainstem stg: cd2, cd3, cd4 mam: b12, b34 stg: ab4, cd1 mam: c12, c34 stg: ab1, ab2, ab3 mam: a12, a34

18a the spinal cord back to exercise selection next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the structure of the spinal cord, including its meninges and their associated spaces. describe the structural and functional organization of the spinal cord grey and white matter. identify and describe the regional differences in the spinal cord, including as seen in cross section. identify and describe the components of the pns, inc. spinal nerves, nerve roots, anterior horn cells, dorsal root ganglia, rami and the neuromuscular junction. identify and describe dermatomes and myotomes and their relationships to peripheral nerves, spinal nerves and spinal cord segments. apply the knowledge of key dermatomes and myotomes to the localization of lesions explain the relationship between peripheral nerves, spinal nerves, and spinal segments

18a lets start with something you know bilaterally paired spinal nerves emerge from the intervertebral foramen, between adjacent vertebrae, and bifurcate into dorsal and ventral rami. peripheral nerves are formed from the dorsal & ventral rami. some peripheral nerves contain fibres from a single spinal level. examples are the intercostal nerves as well as the nerves derived from dorsal rami that supply intrinsic back muscles and overlying skin. other peripheral nerves are formed in nerve plexuses by contributions from multiple ventral rami and therefore contain contributions from multiple spinal cord levels. examples are the ulnar nerve, which contains fibres from the ventral rami of the c8 and t1 spinal nerves, and the sciatic nerve, which contains fibres from the ventral rami of the l4-s3 spinal nerves. 2 previous next

18a spinal segments 3 previous next youll recall from unit 1 that the bilaterally paired spinal nerves are named according to their associated vertebra. the c1 spinal nerves emerge from above the atlas, and so are named according to the vertebra below them. this is consistent down to, and including, the c7 spinal nerve; cervical spinal nerves are named according to the vertebra below. the exception is the c8 spinal nerve, which emerges from below the c7 vertebra. from there on, spinal nerves are named according to the vertebra above. i.e. the t1 spinal nerve emerges from below the t1 vertebra. well move centrally from here to start learning more about the anatomy of the central nervous system. axons within a spinal nerve (or within a peripheral nerve arising from it) come from cell bodies located at a prescribed spinal level or segment . the naming of a spinal segment corresponds to its spinal nerve. thus, the t5 spinal nerve contains axons that arise from cell bodies at the t5 spinal segment. the c8 spinal nerve contains axons that arise from cell bodies at the c8 spinal segment.

18a dermatomes and myotomes 4 previous next youll also recall from unit 1 that each spinal nerve and segment has an associated dermatome and myotome . the upper limb is used here to illustrate this concept. lesion of a given spinal nerve or spinal segment results in a stereotyped loss of sensory input and motor output. this will differ from the stereotyped loss seen with lesion of a peripheral nerve. why?

18a peripheral nerve distribution 5 previous next remember, some peripheral nerves carry fibres from multiple spinal levels. therefore, the cutaneous distribution of a peripheral nerve may include portions of multiple dermatomes you could also look at it this way: a given dermatome may be formed by axons delivered to the skin by more than one peripheral nerve . the pattern of sensory and motor loss can help you determine whether the lesion involves a spinal nerve / segment or a peripheral nerve. for example (use the figures on the previous slide, and this one), suppose a patient shows i) a loss of sensation on the pad of the thumb and the middle finger, and ii) weakness in wrist and finger flexion and thumb abduction and opposition. does this pattern of sensory and motor loss fit a peripheral nerve or a spinal nerve? which specific one? suppose a patient shows i) a loss of sensation over the pad of the middle finger and ii) weakness in elbow, wrist and finger extension, as well as wrist flexion and mild weakness in finger flexion. does this pattern of sensory and motor loss fit a peripheral nerve or a spinal nerve? which specific one?

18a special areas of the cord help localize a lesion 6 previous next the phrenic nucleus is the specific group of somatic motor neurons at the c3 - c5 levels that gives rise to the phrenic nerve. this nucleus is controlled by axons descending from higher centres. spinal cord lesions above this level will paralyze the diaphragm; spinal cord lesions below this level will not. sympathetic outflow from the t1-l2 levels controls sweat glands and vascular resistance, and therefore body temperature. it is subject to descending control from higher centres. lesions that interrupt the flow of information from these higher centres can result in difficulty maintaining body temperature . parasympathetic outflow from the s2-s4 levels gives rise to the pelvic splanchnic nerves, which innervate genital smooth muscle and the internal anal and urethral sphincters. they control reflexive emptying of bowel and bladder and sexual function. somatic motor and sensory outflow, also from the s2-s4 levels, gives rise to the pudendal nerves, which innervate the skeletal muscle and skin of the perineum, respectively . the pudendal nerves control the external anal and urethral sphincters and therefore the voluntary emptying of bowel and bladder. the cell bodies of origin of both the pelvic splanchnic and pudendal nerves are under independent descending control from higher centres, and so spinal cord lesions can cause bowel and bladder incontinence and affect sexual function.

18a key dermatomes in lesion localization 7 previous next c2 back of head c5 shoulder tip c6 thumb c7 middle finger c8 small finger t4 nipple t10 umbilicus l1 inguinal ligament l5 great toe s1 small toe, sole of foot s5 perianal how will you learn these key dermatomes? they remind me of a certain dance learn these key dermatomes first. then, using this framework, fill in the remaining dermatomes of the limbs, as described here: summary of clinically-relevant dermatomes and myotomes for lesion localization

18a coverings of the spinal cord 8 previous next between the bony vertebral canal and the dura is the extradural (epidural) space. it contains a padding layer of adipose and the internal vertebral venous plexus. the dura mater is a thick, tough membrane. deep to the dura is the more delicate arachnoid mater. together, the dura and arachnoid form the dural sac, which surrounds the spinal cord loosely. the cerebrospinal fluid (csf)-filled subarachnoid space separates the arachnoid mater from the delicate pia mater. the hydrostatic pressure of the csf holds the arachnoid against the dura. between the bony surface of the vertebral canal and the spinal cord are layers of adipose, membranes and a fluid-filled space. the meninges are the three layers of membranes that surround and enclose the spinal cord within the vertebral column. from superficial to deep, they are the dura, arachnoid and pia.

18a the dural sac and lumbar cistern 9 previous next during development, the vertebral column continues to grow after the spinal cord stops. as a result, the vertebral canal is significantly longer than the spinal cord. the spinal cord ends as the conus medullaris at the level of the l2 vertebral body. the dural sac extends to the level of the s2 vertebral body. this creates an expanded, csf-filled, subarachoid space between the levels of l2 and s2. this is the lumbar cistern , a clinically-important space from which csf is sampled in a lumbar puncture. see this anatomy clearly in a sagittal mri here:

18a the lumbar cistern in mri 10 previous next this is a sagittal, t2-weighted mri of the lower spine . in this type of image, tissues with a high fluid content emit a high signal (appear white), and tissues with a low fluid content emit a low signal (appear black). tissues with intermediate fluid contents appear various shades of grey. therefore, csf within the subarachnoid space, including the lumbar cistern, appears white, as does the adipose in the hypodermis overlying the sacrum. ligaments and other dense ct structures, which are composed of tightly-packed protein fibres and little tissue fluid, appears black. bone appears grey, and the vertebral bodies are recognizable as grey blocks. how am i able to identify the l5 and s1 vertebral bodies? i use my knowledge of anatomy to find the sacral promontory (a), identifiable as a sharp angle in the alignment of the vertebrae. i count upward to identify the l2 vertebral body and confirm the level of the end of the spinal cord (b). i count downward to the s2 vertebral body and confirm the level of the end of the dural sac (c). this also allows me to identify the l5-s1 intervertebral disc (d) . the two components of the intervertebral disc, the annulus fibrosus and the nucleus pulposus are differentiated by their distinct water content. the annulus fibrosus is composed of fibrocartilage, a very dense form of ct with tightly-packed protein fibres and little interstitial fluid. it therefore appears black. the nucleus pulposus is a highly-hydrated gelatinous tissue that appears relatively bright.

18a the cauda equina 11 previous next another consequence of the disparity between the length of the spinal cord and that of the vertebral canal is the formation of the cauda equina. cervical spinal nerves roots (green) arise from their associated spinal segments roughly adjacent to the intervertebral space through which they pass. more caudal spinal nerve roots must descend through the subarachnoid space to reach the level of their respective intervertebral spaces. lumbar (purple) and sacral (blue) spinal nerve roots extend beyond the caudal tip of the spinal cord to form a mass of nerve roots called the cauda equina. the cauda equina is contained within the lumbar cistern. as spinal nerve roots leave the subarachnoid space, they take a sleeve of arachnoid and dura with them that is continuous with the perineurium, the ct layer that surrounds peripheral nerves.

18a organization of spinal cord white matter 12 previous next you will recall from your neurohistology emodule that white matter is neural tissue rich in axons and oligodendrocytes and grey matter is neural tissue rich in neuronal cell bodies and astrocytes. in the spinal cord, white matter is superficial and grey matter is deep. the spinal cord white matter consists largely of axons that carry sensory information upward, and motor information downward. longitudinal grooves subdivide the spinal cord white matter. the ventral median fissure and dorsal median sulcus separate the spinal cord white matter into right and left sides . the dorsolateral and ventrolateral sulci subdivide the spinal cord white matter into the ventral, lateral and dorsal columns.

18a organization of spinal cord grey matter 13 previous next the grey matter of the spinal cord forms a continuous column that runs throughout its length. at all levels, the spinal cord grey matter forms a butterfly in cross section. its dorsal horn primarily consists of sensory neurons and its ventral horn primarily consists of somatic motor neurons. at certain spinal levels, a lateral horn is also present, which consists of visceral (autonomic )motor neurons.

18a regional variations in the cord 14 previous next the anatomy of the spinal cord is not uniform throughout its length. the cervical (a) and lumbosacral (b) enlargements the innervation of the upper limbs arises from the c5-t1 levels, and that of the lower limbs arises from the l2-s3 levels. at these levels the ventral horns are enlarged to accommodate the cell bodies of the somatic motor neurons that innervate the limbs. preganglionic autonomic neurons sympathetic preganglionic neuronal cell bodies are present between the t1 and l2 levels. they occupy a position intermediate to the dorsal and ventral horns, where they form distinct lateral horns (c). they give rise to the sympathetic outflow to the entire body. parasympathetic preganglionic neuronal cell bodies are present between the s2 and s4 levels. they, too, occupy a position intermediate to the dorsal and ventral horns (d). however, because the ventral horns are greatly enlarged at these levels, these neurons do not form a distinct lateral horn. these neurons give rise to the axons which form the pelvic splanchnic nerves. from the human brain in photographs and diagrams, by john nolte

18a information is segregated within the cns 15 previous next peripheral nerves contain both sensory fibres carrying information toward the cns and motor fibres carrying information away from the cns, to peripheral targets. these modalities, which are mixed at the level of the spinal nerve, are segregated at the level of the spinal nerve roots. sensory information from somatic and visceral sources in the periphery enters the spinal cord via the dorsal roots. the cell bodies of these sensory neurons are located in the dorsal root ganglia (drg). many of these sensory neurons synapse onto neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. motor information destined for both somatic and visceral targets leaves the spinal cord via the ventral roots. the cell bodies of somatic motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord. the cell bodies of any visceral motor neurons are located in an intermediate position between the dorsal and ventral horns. if they are sympathetic, they form the lateral horns of t1-l2. if they are parasympathetic, they are restricted to levels s2-s4 lesions of ventral horn cells, spinal nerves or their roots causes sensory and / or motor signs in a dermatomal / myotomal distribution.
18a quiz previous youve reached the end of this slm. do you want to go to quizlandia? hmmm, why not? go to the quiz sorry, busy now. im setting up a date for tonight. skip the quiz next
previous congratulations on finishing prelab slm 18a! back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review 18a review 18a review 18a

18.4 field trip the specimens in grants museum are organized by body region. the museum section on the thorax is relevant to this lab. it has excellent dissections of the spinal cord in situ, and the brain and its coverings. review them when next you are in grants museum. back to exercise selection

18b meninges and intracranial bleeds back to exercise selection next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the cranial meninges and intervening spaces, both potential and real describe dural reflections and dural venous sinuses describe the relationship of cerebral vasculature to the cranial meninges describe the relationship of the middle meningeal arteries to the coverings of the brain and their clinical significance describe the location in which blood accumulates in epidural and subdural hematomas, and in subarachnoid hemorrhage, and learn to recognize the appearance of these different types of intracranial bleeds in mri

18b meninges 2 previous next like the spinal cord, the brain is covered by three layers of meninges: a) a tough outer layer (dura mater), b) an intermediate spider - web like layer (the arachnoid mater), and c) a thin, delicate layer (pia mater) that adheres to the brain and spinal cord. like the spinal cord, the pia is thin and closely adhered to the surface of the brain. the arachnoid is a looser covering, and the csf-filled subarachnoid space separates the pia and the arachnoid. similar to the lumbar cistern associated with the spinal cord, in some places the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain is expanded, forming csf-filled subarachnoid cisterns. unlike the spinal cord, associated with the cranial meninges are venous blood-filled spaces, called the dural venous sinuses. these are not called veins because, as you know from your histology emodules, veins are trilaminar structures, consisting of a tunica intima, tunica media and tunica adventitia (externa). the venous-blood filled spaces associated with the cranial meninges do not have this structure, and so cannot be called veins. because they contain blood, however, they are lined by endothelium.

18b the cranial dura 3 previous next unlike the spinal dura, the cranial dura consists of two layers: the periosteal and meningeal layers. the periosteal layer of the dura is, in fact, the periosteum lining the inner surface of the skull. as it is anchored into the bone matrix by collagenous penetrating fibres, it is very tightly adhered to the skull. for the most part, the meningeal layer of the dura adheres to the inner surface of the periosteal layer, forming a single bilaminar structure, the cranial dura. the exceptions occur where the meningeal layer of the dura separates from the periosteal layer to fold inward, forming rigid partitions that separate subdivisions of the brain. these partitions are called dural reflections. an example is the falx cerebri, which separates the right and left cerebral hemispheres. along the lines of attachment of the dural reflections, intracranial venous structures are created between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura. these spaces, which contain venous blood, are the dural venous sinuses. an example is the superior sagittal sinus.

18b cerebral vessels in the subarachnoid space 4 previous next the relationships of the arachnoid mater, subarachnoid space and the pia mater in the cranium are the same as the spinal meninges: the arachnoid and pia mater are separated by the subarachnoid space, which contains csf. the hydrostatic pressure of the csf holds the arachnoid mater against the dura mater. the delicate pia mater is closely adhered to the surface of the brain, and cannot be separated from it, nor discerned with the naked eye. the subarachnoid space contains the cerebral arteries and veins. a bleed in this space is a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and usually is the result of the tearing or rupture of cerebral arteries. because arterial blood is under pressure, a subarachnoid hemorrhage usually develops very rapidly.

18b subarachnoid hemorrhage 5 previous next csf is black in ct, as seen here in the lateral ventricles (a). acute blood (a bleed) is white in ct. in a subarachnoid hemorrhage, a cerebral artery bleeds into the subarachnoid space. acute blood (white) is seen in spaces normally filled with csf (black), such as sulci (b) and cisterns (c). blood in the sulci makes the gyri easier to see; this is called gyral enhancement. axial ct sagittal ct

18b cerebral veins and arachnoid granulations 6 previous next cerebral veins coalesce, then cross the arachnoid mater and the meningeal layer of the dura to empty into the dural venous sinuses. where they cross the meningeal layer of the dura, the outer wall of the cerebral veins are fused to the meningeal layer of the dura, and seal off the csf-filled subarachnoid space from the venous blood-filled dural venous sinus. cerebral veins can tear at the point at which they fuse to the meningeal layer of the dura. in this scenario, venous blood accumulates in the plane between the meningeal layer of the dura and the arachnoid mater. as the pressure mounts with the accumulation of blood, it pushes the two layers apart and creates a pathological subdural space. this is a subdural hematoma. the subdural space is, under normal conditions,a potential space, because it onlyexists in a pathological scenario. arachnoid granulations are out-pouchings of arachnoid mater through the meningeal layer of the dura into the superior sagittal sinus. csf is extruded into venous blood across the arachnoid granulations.

18b subdural hematoma 7 previous next csf is black in ct, as seen here in the lateral ventricles (a). acute blood (a bleed) is white in ct (b). in a subdural hematoma, venous blood accumulates between the dura and arachnoid. only the pressure of the csf must be overcome in order to separate these layers. these bleeds usually develop more slowly than a subarachnoid hemorrhage, because they involve venous blood, which is under low pressure, rather than arterial blood, which is under high pressure. subdural hematomas appear crescent-shaped, as suture lines between the cranial bones do not limit the expansion of the bleed. it is thus said that a subdural hematoma does not respect suture lines. an intracranial bleed can act as a space-occupying lesion and cause a midline shift, as seen here with dotted line c. axial ct

18b cranial and spinal meninges 8 previous next at the foramen magnum, through which the brainstem is continuous with the spinal cord, the periosteal and meningeal layers of the cranial dura mater separate. there, the periosteal layer of the cranial dura reflects onto the outer surface of the skull where it is simply the periosteum covering the external surface of the cranium. this layer is therefore not present in the vertebral column. the meningeal layer of the cranial dura, however, passes through the foramen magnum and is continuous with the spinal dura mater. a consequence of this arrangement of cranial dura is that, under normal circumstances, in the cranium there is no extradural (epidural) space, as is found in the vertebral column. you will recall that the extradural space in the vertebral column is a real space filled with fat and the internal vertebral venous plexus. in the cranium, the extradural space is, however, a potential space. it is created under pathological conditions in an extradural hematoma. the arachnoid mater, subarachnoid space, and pia mater surrounding the brain is continuous with that surrounding the spinal cord.

18b meningeal arteries are superficial to the dura 9 previous next the meningeal arteries are located between the inner surface of the skull bone and the periosteal layer of dura. the largest meningeal artery is the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the external carotid artery that passes into the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum. the position of the middle meningeal artery between the inner surface of the skull bone and the periosteal layer of dura has clinical significance in traumatic injuries to the skull. the skull is thinnest and most fragile at the pterion, where four cranial bones come together: the frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones. a branch of the middle meningeal artery crosses the pterion, where skull fractures are common. tearing of the middle meningeal artery can cause an extradural (epidural) hematoma.

18b extradural hematoma 10 previous next axial ct coronal ct csf is black in ct, as seen here in the lateral ventricles (a). acute blood (a bleed) is white in ct (b). in an extradural hematoma, arterial blood accumulates between the periosteal layer of the dura and the cranial bone. the high pressure of the arterial blood tears the periosteum away from the bone and creates an extradural space. extradural hematomas often involve an initial lucid period during which the patient may deny serious injury, and may not seek medical attention. this can then be followed by a rapid decline. extradural hematomas appear lens-shaped, in contrast to the crescent shape of the subdural hematoma and the classic gyral enhancement of the subarachnoid hemorrhage. the lens-shaped occurs as extradural hematomas respect suture lines. as you can see in both of these images, the bleed is restricted to the inner surface of the parietal bone. again, an intracranial bleed can act as a space-occupying lesion and cause a midline shift, as seen here with dotted line c.

18b summary of bleeds associated with the meninges previous next this slm introduces you to the meninges and their clinical significance wrt bleeds, which are summarized in the accompanying diagram. realize, that there are bleed associated with the brain, itself. the rupture of a penetrating branch of a cerebral artery causes an intraparenchymal bleed. as the name suggests, in this case blood accumulates in the brain tissue, itself. this can occur in cases of trauma or as a result of a hemorrhagic stroke. alternatively, blood can accumulate within a ventricle. you will learn more about these types of bleeds later in cpc-3. 11

18.3 the brainstem and cranial nerves back to exercise selection specimens wet full brain, wet half brain model of brainstem plastinated brainstems functional neuroanatomy, available from the cpc-3 course website, under the anatomy > unit 6 neuroanatomy tab. next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: identify / describe the major features of the brainstem. identify / describe cranial nerves (their targets, functions, brainstem attachment, and the effects of their lesioning). identify brainstem cross-sections at six levels, based on your newly-acquired knowledge of the anatomy of the brainstem 18.3 objectives 2 previous next

18.3 brainstem subdivisions 3 previous next the brain stem is subdivided into the midbrain, pons and medulla. the following two figures, like the brainstem models supplied, include the thalamus, caudate nucleus, putamen and part of the corona radiata in addition to the brain stem. using these materials, t a s k from basic clinical neuroscience, 2nd ed., by p.a. young, p.h. young, and d.l. tolbert, 2008. some of the more delicate structures, such as the ivth cranial nerve, may be missing from your specimen. if so, try to find them on another specimen in the room. learning the surface features of the brainstem makes it much easier to: 1) understand the effects of extramedullary lesions , 2) learn to identify different brainstem levels in cross-section and 3) learn which deep structures are found at each brainstem level. these abilities are the key to lesion localization. at the centre table, you will find brainstem models, plastinated brainstems and wet brainstems. as well as the wet brains at your station, identify the features labelled in the diagrams on the following two slides.

18.3 features of the ventral brainstem 4 previous next identify the following features on the ventral aspect of the brainstem. tas k from basic clinical neuroscience, 2nd ed., by p.a. young, p.h. young, and d.l. tolbert, 2008.

18.3 cranial nerves: a summary, pt. 1 5 previous next you know that all spinal nerves contain voluntary motor fibres, general sensory fibres and sympathetic postganglionic fibres. as you learned in the head and neck block of first year anatomy, cranial nerves vary in their composition; some are purely motor, some purely sensory and some are mixed. cranial nerves, like spinal nerves never cross the midline; i.e. they innervate their targets ipsilaterally. ill recap the cranial nerves here, by grouping them according to function: purely special sensory: cranial nerve i, the olfactory nerve , senses odorant molecules in the air, which we perceive as smell; a lesion of this nerve causes anosmia cranial nerve ii, the optic nerve , senses light energy, perceived as vision; its lesion causes blindness cranial nerve viii, the vestibulocochlear nerve, senses: i) balance , and ii) sound energy which we perceive as hearing ; lesions can cause imbalance (more in week 41) and hearing loss largely voluntary motor: cranial nerves iii, iv, and vi, the oculomotor , trochlear and abducens nerves, control extraocular eye muscles, the voluntary muscles that position the eye in the orbit. the abducens nerve abducts the eye, the trochlear nerve depresses the adducted eye, the oculomotor nerve controls all other eye mvts. a lesion of these nerves causes the affected eye to be misaligned (strabismus) cranial nerve iii, the oculomotor nerve, also carries parasympathetic fibres destined to control smooth muscle in the eye; e.g. it causes pupillary constriction, and if lesioned, the pupil is large (mydriasis) cranial nerve xi, the accessory nerve, controls the trapezius (shoulder shrug) and sternocleidomastoid (turning the head) cranial nerve xii, the hypoglossal nerve , moves the tongue; a lesion of the hypoglossal nerve paralyzes the ipsilateral tongue; on attempted protrusion of the tongue, the non-paralyzed side dominates, and pushes the tongue toward the weakened side

18.3 cranial nerves: a summary, pt. 2 6 previous next that took care of 8 of the 12 cranial nerves; not so bad, so far! the last 4 are a little more complicated. largely general sensory: cranial nerve v, the trigeminal nerve , is sensory to the skin of the face. it consists of the ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular subdivisions. the trigeminal nerve is also motor to the muscles of mastication; a lesion causes weakness in, and atrophy of, these muscles cranial nerves vii, ix and x have small areas of general sensory responsibility, largely associated with the external ear and ear canal (vii and x) and the pharyngotympanic tube (ix) the final three are pretty much a mixed bag: cranial nerve vii, the facial nerve , controls the muscles of facial expression; if lesioned, the ipsilateral face is weakened or paralyzed the facial nerve also carries parasympathetic fibres destined to control secretion of the the lacrimal, submandibular and sublingual glands, as well as the mucosa of the nasal and oral cavities the facial nerve receives taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue as noted above, it carries general sensory fibres from portions of the external ear cranial nerve ix, the glossopharyngeal nerve , receives taste and general sensory fibres from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue it also carries parasympathetic fibres destined to control secretion of the parotid gland cranial nerve x, the vagus nerve , carries parasympathetic fibres destined to supply thoracic and much of the abdominal viscera it is motor to the muscles of the larynx (speech) and pharynx (swallowing); its lesioning causes a hoarse voice and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

18.3 the cerebellum must be removed to view the dorsal brainstem 7 previous next three paired masses of white matter connect the cerebellum to the dorsal aspect of the brainstem: the superior cerebellar peduncles connect the midbrain and cerebellum the middle cerebellar peduncles connect the pons and cerebellum the inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the medulla and cerebellum. the cerebellum overlies the fourth ventricle. once the peduncles are cut, one sees the floor of the fourth ventricle on the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. from basic clinical neuroscience, 2nd ed., by p.a. young, p.h. young, and d.l. tolbert, 2008.

18.3 features of the dorsal brainstem 8 previous next identify the following features on the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. tas k from basic clinical neuroscience, 2nd ed., by p.a. young, p.h. young, and d.l. tolbert, 2008.

18.3 external features of the brain stem as seen in cross section 9 previous next in the following exercise, you will study the silhouettes of cross-sections through the brainstem at six different levels. the shape of the silhouette identifies the brainstem level. throughout the exercise, refer to the illustrations of the brainstem, the brainstem model, and your brainstem specimens to identify the surface features and spaces indicated. following completion of this exercise, you will be able to identify brainstem cross-sections based on their silhouette. you will then use this skill to identify brainstem levels in mri. note that all cross-sections are in patient presentation; i.e. dorsal down.

18.3 the midbrain in cross section 10 previous next click here for the answer key: with reference to the illustrations of the brainstem provided, the brainstem models, and your brainstem specimens, identify surface features and spaces a through e. the rostral midbrain the caudal midbrain

18.3 the midbrain in mri 11 previous next many of these features are easily identifiable in mri. in this image, identify: the cerebral peduncles reaching anteriorly the interpeduncular fossa, between them the cerebral aqueduct the colliculi, posteriorly some people say a cross section of the midbrain reminds them of mickey mouse , his ears being the peduncles. this characteristic shape, with the cerebral peduncles reaching anteriorly, with the interpeduncular fossa in between, and the colliculi located posteriorly identifies the midbrain in mri.

18.3 the pons in cross section 12 previous next click here for the answer key: with reference to the illustrations of the brainstem provided, the brainstem model, and your brainstem specimens, identify surface features and spaces a through e. identify the belly of the pons arching ventrally. notice how this time he cerebellar peduncles reach posteriorly toward the cerebellum with the 4th ventricle in between. this characteristic shape, with the belly of the pons arching anteriorly, and the cerebellar peduncles reaching posteriorly with the 4th ventricle in between, identifies the pons in mri. the mid-pons the caudal pons

18.3 the mid-pons in mri 13 previous next many of these features are easily identifiable in mri. in this image of the midpons, identify: the belly of the pons, anteriorly the middle cerebellar peduncles, larger and more lateral the superior cerebellar peduncles, smaller and more medial the fourth ventricle

18.3 the caudal pons in mri 14 previous next many of these features are easily identifiable in mri. in this image of the caudal pons, identify: the belly of the pons, anteriorly the middle cerebellar peduncles, at this level very large and continuous with the cerebellum the fourth ventricle the location of the facial colliculi in the floor of the fourth ventricle some say that a cross section of the caudal pons reminds them of a silhouette of darth vaders head.

18.3 the medulla in cross section 15 previous next with reference to the illustrations of the brainstem provided, the brainstem model, and your brainstem specimens, identify surface features and spaces a through g. this characteristic shape with the pyramids ventrally, and at more rostral levels, the olives lateral to the pyramids and the inferior cerebellar peduncles reaching posteriorly, identifies the medulla in mri. the rostral, or open medulla the caudal, or closed medulla the fourth ventricle is associated with the rostral midbrain. it is an expanded, or open portion of the ventricular system, as compared to the narrow central canal seen at the caudal, or closed medulla. click here for the answer key:

18.3 the open medulla in mri 16 previous next many of these features are easily identifiable in mri. in this image of the caudal pons, identify: the medullary pyramids, anteriorly the location of the olives, posterolateral to the pyramids the inferior cerebellar peduncles, reaching posteriorly the fourth ventricle posteriorly, between the medulla and cerebellum

18.3 the closed medulla 17 previous next in this image of the caudal pons, identify: the medullary pyramids, anteriorly notice that at this level, the brainstem is quite similar in cross-sectional shape to the spinal cord.

18.2 objectives 2 previous next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe / identify the coverings of the brain, including: the anatomy of the cranial cavity the meninges and intervening spaces dural reflections and dural venous sinuses the relationship of the middle meningeal arteries to the dura mater and skull and their clinical significance.

18.2 dural reflections 3 previous next reflections. there you will also find a wet sample of dura mater and a tray to work on. on the outer surface of the lateral aspect of the wet dura, look for branches of the middle place the wet dura on the whole brain at your station, positioning the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli correctly, as follows: the falx lies between the cerebral hemispheres in the median longitudinal fissure, and the tentorium cerebelli lies between the brain and cerebellum in the transverse fissure. observe: what major brain structure passes through the tentorial notch? go to the centre of the room to study the plastinated head dissected to show the dural tas k meningeal arteries. what space is created with tearing of the middle meningeal arteries? what is this condition called? on both specimens, in the midsagittal plane, identify the falx cerebri. on both specimens, identify the tentorium cerebelli and the tentorial notch.

18.2 dural venous sinuses i 4 previous next recall that the dural venous sinuses are located along the line of attachment of the dural reflections, that they receive blood from the cerebral veins, and that they empty into the internal jugular veins at the jugular foramen. you will now begin to trace the dural venous sinuses. identify the inferior sagittal sinus in the free (inferior) edge of the falx cerebri. identify the continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus as the straight sinus along the line of attachment of the falx cerebri with the tentorium cerebelli. identify the confluence of sinuses, the point at which the straight sinus meets the superior sagittal sinus. tas k on both specimens, in the attached (superior) edge of the falx cerebri, identify the superior sagittal sinus.

18.2 dural venous sinuses ii 5 previous next anteriorly, identify the attachment of the tentorium cerebelli to the petrous ridge, a feature of the petrous temporal bone. within this line of attachment, identify the superior petrosal sinus. identify the tentorial notch, the opening in the tentorium cerebelli, through which the brainstem passes. if it has not already been done, use scissors to cut open the superior sagittal sinus in the wet sample of dura and identify the arachnoid granulations. what forms the arachnoid granulations and what purpose do they serve? return these specimens to the centre table. on only the plastinated specimen, identify the right and left transverse sinuses along tas k the line of attachment of the tentorium cerebelli to the occipital bone.

18.2 arachnoid mater 6 previous next note how bridges over the sulci (grooves) and other irregularities on the surface of the brain. can you identify all the numbered structures and spaces? click here for the answer: using the whole brain at your station, examine the arachnoid mater. tas k note the presence of vessels deep to the arachnoid matter, these are cerebral arteries and veins. what is the name of the space deep to the arachnoid mater that contains cerebral arteries and veins? what fluid fills this space? what is the name given to the accumulation of blood in this space with rupture of a cerebral artery? the pia mater is closely adhered to the surface of the brain and cannot be pulled away without damaging the underlying brain tissue.

18.2 progress check 1 7 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: on the wet specimen of dura and / or the plastinated head, as appropriate, identify the falx cerebri, tentorium cerebelli, tentorial notch, middle meningeal arteries, superior and inferior sagittal sinuses, straight sinus, confluence of sinuses, transverse sinuses, superior petrosal sinuses and arachnoid granulations. in what space does the falx cerebri lie? in what space does the tentorium cerebelli lie? what part of the cns passes through the tentorial notch? what condition results from the tearing of the middle meningeal arteries? what vessels, in general, empty into the dural venous sinuses? into what vessels do the dural venous sinuses ultimately empty? on the wet brain, identify the arachnoid matter and, deep to it, the cerebral arteries and veins. in what space are these vessels? what name is given to an accumulation of blood here? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

18.2 the interior of the skull 8 previous next notice, as illustrated below on the left, that the base of the skull is divided into an anterior, middle and posterior cranial fossae. notice that each of these subdivisions of the skull base is at a different level. each houses a different major region of the brain. remove the calvaria from the skull so that you can study the interior skull base. tas k the key to understanding the base of the skull is the sphenoid bone. locate the sphenoid bone in the illustration on the right. now find the sphenoid bone in the base of the skull in front of you. you will begin your study of the skull base with the sphenoid bone in the anterior cranial fossa.

18.2 the anterior cranial fossa 9 previous next identify the lesser wing and body of the sphenoid bone, the orbital part of the frontal bone, tas k and the ethmoid bone. these components form the anterior cranial fossa. identify the sharp, sagittally-oriented crista galli, a feature of the ethmoid bone. it serves as attachment for the falx cerebri, anteriorly. identify the anterior clinoid processes. these serve as the anterior attachment of the tentorium cerebelli. identify the foramina of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone; the olfactory nerves, cranial nerves (cn) i, pass through these openings.

18.2 features of the middle cranial fossa 10 identify the body of the sphenoid bone, a feature of which is the sella turcica or pituitary tas k fossa. put an index finger and thumb on either side of the sella turcica; this is the location of the cavernous sinuses, which receive venous blood from the face, via the ophthalmic veins, as well as from the base of the brain. note that the petrous temporal bone tucks in under the greater wing of the sphenoid bone and that a portion of the petrous bone faces upward to contribute to the floor of the middle cranial fossa. identify the sharp dividing line between the middle and posterior fossae, the petrous ridge. previous next

18.2 foramina of the middle cranial fossa 11 previous next optic canal: cn ii (optic n), ophthalmic artery superior orbital fissure: cns iii, iv, v1, vi (oculomotor n, trochlear n, ophthalmic division of the trigeminal n, abducens n) identify the foramina associated with the middle cranial fossa and what passes through each. tas k use the pipe cleaner provided to represent the internal carotid artery in the carotid canal. replicate the carotid siphon lateral to the hypophyseal fossa and arching under the anterior clinoid process. foramen rotundum: cn v2 (maxillary division of the trigeminal n.) foramen ovale: cn v3 (mandibular division of the trigeminal n.) foramen spinosum: middle meningeal a. foramen lacerum; filled with cartilage in life carotid canal: internal carotid a.

18.2 features of the posterior cranial fossa i 12 previous next note that the sphenoid bone is continuous with the occipital bone in the midline, thus forming tas k the clivus, the central, continuous piece of bone running from the pituitary fossa to the foramen magnum. observe that posterior to the petrous ridge, the petrous temporal bone faces the posterior cranial fossa. place the tip of a blunt probe in the jugular foramen and note that one side of this foramen is formed by the petrous temporal bone and the other side by the occipital bone. dural venous sinuses receive blood from cerebral veins and empty into the internal jugular vein at the jugular foramen. dural venous sinuses leave grooves on the internal surface of the skull which allows you to trace the flow of venous blood to the jugular foramen, which you will do next.

18.2 features of the posterior cranial fossa ii 13 previous next near the internal occipital protuberance, identify the grooves left by the transverse sinuses tas k along the internal surface of the occipital bone. at the petrous ridge, identify the point where the transverse sinuses empty into the sigmoid sinuses, and trace the sigmoid sinuses to the jugular foramen. turn your attention back to the location of the cavernous sinuses, on either side of the sella turcica. identify the grooves for the inferior petrosal sinuses, along which venous blood drains from the cavernous sinuses to the jugular foramina. now, put your fingernail into the groove marking the superior petrosal sinus along the apex of the petrous ridge. it, too, drains the cavernous sinus, ultimately to the jugular foramen, but along a more circuitous route. follow it to the point where unites with the transverse sinus. from this point, blood from the superior petrosal sinus and the transverse sinus drain via the sigmoid sinus to the jugular foramen.

18.2 attachment of the tentorium cerebelli 14 previous next dural venous sinuses are formed in the attached edge of the dural reflections, where the meningeal layer of the dura separates and folds inward from the periosteal layer of the dura. dural reflections are rigid partitions that separate different regions of the brain. the tentorium cerebelli forms a roof over the posterior cranial fossa, and separates the brain, above, from the cerebellum, below . the fixed edge of the tentorium cerebelli is attached at the superior petrosal sinuses along the petrous ridges and continues along the lines of attachment of the transverse sinuses. the free edge of the tentorium cerebelli forms the tentorial notch. the compartments above and below the tentorium cerebelli are the supratentorial and infratentorial compartments of the skull.

18.2 foramina of the posterior cranial fossa 15 previous next each. internal acoustic meatus: cns vii & viii (facial n, vestibulocochlear n) jugular foramen: cns ix, x, xi (glossopharyngeal n, vagus n, accessory n) and internal jugular vein hypoglossal canal: cn xii (hypoglossal n) identify the foramina associated with the posterior cranial fossa and what passes through tas k

18.2 the brain in context 16 previous next the foramen magnum is the site of the junction of the spinal cord with the brainstem. the brainstem is in close relationship to the clivus, ventrally. the rostral end of the brainstem, the midbrain, occupies the tentorial notch. the cerebellum is attached to the dorsal aspect of the brainstem and occupies the posterior fossa. the occipital lobes sit on the superior surface of the tentorium cerebelli, the temporal lobes occupy the middle cranial fossa and the frontal lobes occupy the anterior cranial fossa. the tentorium cerebelli subdivides the cranial cavity into a supratentorial compartment, which contains the cerebral hemispheres, and an infratentorial compartment, which contains the brainstem and cerebellum. now you can relate the components of the brain to the bones and dura.

18.1 objectives 2 previous next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe / identify the general anatomy of the brain and its coverings, including the surface features of the brain (sulci, fissures, lobes, gyri) inc. functional localization. describe the effects of lesions in various cortical locations, based on your knowledge of functional localization in the cerebral hemispheres. describe the components and general functions of the diencephalon. name the structures included in the limbic system and describe their basic functions.

18.1 surface features of the brain 3 previous next in this exercise, you will study the anatomical features of a cerebral hemisphere as seen from three different aspects: i) superolateral, ii) medial and iii) inferior, and correlate these features with function. the surface of the cerebrum has many folds called gyri (s. gyrus) and grooves between the folds called sulci (s. sulcus). particularly deep sulci are sometimes called fissures. gyri and sulci vary somewhat between individuals, but there are certain constant gyri and sulci that are named. using these surface features as landmarks, the cerebral hemisphere is subdivided into lobes that have specific functional characteristics. preparing to study the brain at your station, retrieve the wet half brain from the bucket. if the arachnoid mater is intact , you will recognize it because it spans the sulci and the other irregularities on the surface of the brain. through the arachnoid, you will be able to see the cerebral blood vessels which occupy the subarachnoid space. peel away the arachnoid mater from the surfaces of the half brain. the blood vessels will come off with the arachnoid. leave the arachnoid intact on the whole brain for now. once the surfaces have been cleared of arachnoid mater, you will identify the major sulci and gyri. the pia mater cannot be identified at the gross level.

18.1 superolateral surface: fissures and major sulci 4 previous lateral fissure: separates the frontal and temporal lobes. gently separate the edges of the lateral fissure to view the cortex of the insula in the floor of the lateral fissure. median longitudinal fissure: separates the right and left cerebral hemispheres. which dural reflection occupies this fissure ? identify the following features of the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k transverse fissure: completely separates the cerebrum from the cerebellum. which dural reflection occupies the transverse fissure? central sulcus: separates the frontal and parietal lobes. identify it between two parallel gyri, the precentral and postcentral gyri. intraparietal sulcus: runs roughly horizontally, separating the superior parietal lobule from the inferior parietal lobule. parieto-occipital fissure: look for this fissure on the medial surface of the hemisphere. it extends only a short distance onto the superior aspect of the hemisphere. superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d. next

18.1 superolateral surface: lobes 5 previous next identify the lobes of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k frontal lobe: extending from the frontal pole to the central sulcus. parietal lobe: extending from the central sulcus to an imaginary line joining the parieto-occipital fissure and the preoccipital notch . temporal lobe: below the lateral fissure and extending posteriorly to the same imaginary line described above. occipital lobe: posterior to the parietal and temporal lobes. superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 superolateral surface: gyri i 6 previous next identify the major gyri of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k precentral gyrus: parallel and anterior to the central sulcus. this is primary motor cortex. superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri: run roughly horizontally from the frontal pole to the precentral gyrus. within the inferior frontal gyrus, identify the opercular and triangular portions, which are the location of broca's area, the motor speech area. superior, middle, inferior temporal gyri run roughly parallel to the lateral fissure, along the length of the temporal lobe. the posterior one third of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere forms wernicke's (auditory association) area where sounds encoding language are recognized. superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 superolateral surface: gyri ii 7 previous next identify the major gyri of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k transverse temporal gyri: buried in the lateral fissure, on the superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus. you must gently open the lateral fissure to see the transverse temporal gyri. they extend from halfway along the upper part of the superior temporal gyrus into the depths of the lateral fissure, ending in the posterior insula. the transverse temporal gyri are primary auditory cortex, where auditory stimuli are perceived. postcentral gyrus: parallel and posterior to the central sulcus. this is primary somatosensory cortex where sensation from the surface of the body is perceived. superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 superolateral surface: gyri iii 8 previous next identify the major gyri of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k superior parietal lobule: above the intraparietal sulcus. inferior parietal lobule: below the intraparietal sulcus. it is further subdivided into the supramarginal and angular gyri. identify the supramarginal gyrus where it surrounds the upturned end of the lateral fissure. similarly, follow the sulcus separating the superior and middle temporal gyri into the parietal lobe, where you will find the angular gyrus surrounding its upturned end. superolateral view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 progress check 1 previous next 9 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the median longitudinal fissure and transverse fissure (what occupies each?), lateral fissure, insula, central sulcus, intraparietal sulcus, parieto-occipital fissure. identify the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes. on the superolateral surface, identify the precentral gyrus (function?), superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri, the opercular and triangular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus (function? dont give the eponym, tell me what happens here!), superior, middle and inferior temporal gyri (function of posterior 1/3 of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere? dont give the eponym, tell me what happens here!), transverse temporal gyri (function?), postcentral gyrus (function?), superior and inferior parietal lobules and the supramarginal and angular gyri of the inferior parietal lobule. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

18.1 medial surface: lobes 10 previous next identify the lobes the cerebral hemisphere on its medial aspect. tas k frontal: separated from the parietal lobe by the central sulcus. the central sulcus does not extend very far onto the medial surface of the hemisphere. occipital: posterior to the parieto-occipital fissure. temporal: anterior to the occipital lobe and below the midline structures of the diencephalon. parietal: posterior to the central sulcus and anterior to the parieto-occipital fissure. medial view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 medial surface: sulci / fissures 11 previous next identify the sulci and fissures of the medial surface. tas k calcarine sulcus: on the medial surface of the occipital lobe. the gyri superior and inferior to the calcarine fissure constitute primary visual cortex, where visual stimuli are perceived. parieto-occipital fissure: a very deep groove that separates the parietal and occipital lobes. medial view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 medial surface: gyri 11 previous next identify the gyri of the medial surface. tas k first identify the corpus callosum which arches anteriorly to posteriorly, inferior to the frontal and parietal lobes. it consists of masses of axons connecting the two cerebral hemispheres across medial view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d. cingulate gyrus: superior to, and running parallel with, the corpus callosum. it is continuous with the parahippocampal gyrus at the splenium of the corpus callosum. these gyri are components of the limbic system, which is involved in emotion, memory and mood. parahippocampal gyrus: the most medial part of the temporal lobe. its most anterior part ends with a hook called the uncus. the parahippocampal gyrus contains the hippocampus. the midline. the axons are transected when the hemispheres are cut apart. identify its subdivisions, the rostrum, genu, body and splenium.

18.1 medial surface: the diencephalon 13 previous next identify other major features of the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere. tas k the diencephalon includes the thalamus, hypothalamus and the epithalamus. the key to identifying the components of the diencephalon is to use three structures as landmarks. identify the optic chiasm , the mammillary body , and the anterior commissure . these three landmarks define the corners of a triangle enclosing the hypothalamus. identify the location of the pituitary stalk between the optic chiasma and the mammillary body. identify the hypothalamic sulcus, a groove superoposterior to a line joining the anterior commissure and the mammillary body. this is the border between the hypothalamus, below, and the thalamus above. identify the pineal gland posterior to the thalamus. it is the largest, and most identifiable feature of the epithalamus . medial view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d.

18.1 medial surface: ventricles 14 previous next begin by identifying the septum pellucidum, tas k attached above to the corpus callosum and below to the fornix . the septum pellucidum separates the right and left lateral ventricles. identify the interventricular foramen by passing a blunt probe through the opening between the fornix and the anterior pole of the thalamus. the tip of your probe is in the lateral ventricle. medial view of the right cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissections of the human brainby carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d. the cns develops from a hollow tube, the lumen of which persists as the ventricular system. each of the major subdivisions of the cns has a component of the ventricular system associated with it. within each cerebral hemisphere is a lateral ventricle. each opens, independently, via an interventricular foramen into the third ventricle. the third ventricle is a midline slit that separates the bilaterally-paired thalami.

18.1 inferior surface 15 previous next gently tip the cerebellum and brainstem aside as needed to see the structures listed below. tas k identify the olfactory tract and bulb, traditionally called cranial nerve i (olfactory nerve), although these structures are parts of the cns. identify the cut surfaces of the optic nerves, optic chiasma and optic tract. traditionally the optic nerve is called cranial nerve ii, however, like the olfactory nerve, the optic nerve is a cns tract. posterior to the optic chiasm identify the base of the hypothalamus, represented by the infundibulum (pituitary stalk) and mammillary bodies. posterior to the mammillary bodies, locate the cerebral peduncles, masses of motor axons descending from the cerebral cortex, between which lies a space, the interpeduncular fossa. identify the most medial gyrus of the temporal lobe, the parahippocampal gyrus. it ends as the uncus, or hook.

18.1 progress check 2 previous next 16 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere, identify the four lobes, the calcarine sulcus (function of gyri above and below?), the parieto-occipital fissure, corpus callosum (what is it?) and its rostrum genu, body and splenium, the cingulate gyrus and parahippocampal gyrus (with what system and functions are these last two gyri associated?), thalamus, hypothalamus and epithalamus, optic chiasm, mammillary body, and anterior commissure, the location of the pituitary stalk, hypothalamic sulcus, pineal gland. identify the septum pellucidum and fornix, the interventricular foramen and the location of the lateral and third ventricles. on the inferior surface, identify the olfactory tract and bulb, optic nerves, optic chiasma and optic tract, mammillary bodies, location of the pituitary stalk, cerebral peduncles, interpeduncular fossa, parahippocampal gyrus and uncus. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.
18.1 quiz previous next 17 no time like the present! go to the quiz later, gator! skip the quiz youve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to go to quizlandia now?
